posts.cooked:
Hello, we were trying to set up a NEO brushless motor and Spark Max motor controller with the Rev Hardware Client before attaching it to anything.  It isn’t spinning using the hardware client; we don’t even see the small jerks others mentioned when running into similar issues.  It’s connected via USB, the encoder wire is plugged in, and we have the power wires connected with Anderson connectors.  Noting is connected in the CAN/PWM port.

There’s a blinking magenta light before I start to to run it, and the light goes to solid magenta as I run it.  I get blinking to solid green as I ramp up in the forward direction, and the same in red as I ramp up in the reverse direction.

I’ll post our configuration below, and we did click “Burn Flash”.  I also looked at the voltage and current in the telemetry data, and I’ve posted that below as well.  The output current seems to stick at zero which makes me wonder if there’s a wiring issue with the connectors.

Has anyone run into this one before?

SparkMax Setting 1018×509 38 KB SparkMax Telemetry 1030×285 18.1 KB

SparkMax Setting 1018×509 38 KB

SparkMax Setting 1018×509 38 KB

SparkMax Telemetry 1030×285 18.1 KB

SparkMax Telemetry 1030×285 18.1 KB
It must be disconnected from the CAN network and rebooted/power cycled after you have removed it from the CAN network.
We typically unplug a CAN wire from the RIO when we want to test using the client.

I’ll keep that in mind, but we hadn’t hooked it up to the CAN network yet since we were just setting it (and the Spark Max) up before connecting it; it was only connected via USB.  I did cycle the power a few times while troubleshooting, but it didn’t get us anywhere.

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked: What is your firmware version? 1.6.3 fixed a bug that sounds like this.
Looking at it again, we have 1.6.3 for the firmware
Sorry, thank you for your help everyone!  It turned out it was not properly connected, and the team members redoing the Anderson connectors have got it spinning.

suggested_topics.excerpt: Sounds like the motor is too directly connected to the battery. Trace the wiring and make sure the motor is connected only to the output of the SparkMax.
